snippet: Interviews with multiple officials in the Obama administration paint a portrait of a president forced by the unexpectedly rapid deterioration of security in Iraq to abandon his longstanding reluctance to use military force.
abstract: Obama administration officials, in interviews, paint portrait of president forced to abandon longstanding reluctance to military force as conditions rapidly deteriorated in Iraq; looming over intensive deliberations and decision to return United States to war was specter of 2012 attack on US diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER, ALISSA J. RUBIN, MARK MAZZETTI and HELENE COOPER

lead_paragraph: Interviews with multiple officials in the Obama administration paint a portrait of a president forced by the unexpectedly rapid deterioration of security in Iraq to abandon his longstanding reluctance to use military force.

headline.main: Fear of ‘Another Benghazi’ Drove White House to Airstrikes in Iraq

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
